title: How to Import an Image in Photoshop as a New Layer or File

steps.title: Open Photoshop and click File.
steps.content: Open Photoshop and click File . It's in the menu bar at the top of the screen. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click Open.
steps.content: Click Open . This will open a file browser you can use to browse images. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Navigate to and select an image.
steps.content: Navigate to and select an image. Use the file browser window to browse files on your computer. Click on an image to select it.

steps.title: Click Open.
steps.content: Click Open . This will open the image in Photoshop. Alternatively, you can click Open on the opening screen of Photoshop and browse an image and open it.

steps.title: Navigate to the image you want to add to Photoshop.
steps.content: Navigate to the image you want to add to Photoshop. This could be an image from the Internet or one you already have on your computer.

steps.title: Copy the image.
steps.content: Copy the image. If you're copying from the web, right-click the image (or, if you’re on a Mac without a right mouse button, Ctrl -click) and choose Copy image . If you're copying an image you already have on your computer, open the image up in your image previewer software, then right-click the image (or Ctrl -click on a Mac) and choose Copy image . Simply copying the image file without opening it first won't copy the image.

steps.title: Create a new image in Photoshop, or open an existing image.
steps.content: Create a new image in Photoshop, or open an existing image. You can do this easily by pressing Ctrl + N (Windows)/ ⌘ Cmd + N (Mac) to make a new image or Ctrl + O (Windows)/ ⌘ Cmd + O (Mac) to open an image.

steps.title: Paste the copied image into your Photoshop image.
steps.content: Paste the copied image into your Photoshop image. You can do this by going to Edit > Paste or by pressing Ctrl + V (Windows)/ ⌘ Cmd + V (Mac). [3] X Research source

steps.title: Open Photoshop and open an image or Photoshop file.
steps.content: Open Photoshop and open an image or Photoshop file. You can either open an existing Photoshop file or image, or create a new Photoshop file.

steps.title: Click File.
steps.content: Click File . It's in the menu bar at the top of the screen. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Click Place.
steps.content: Click Place . This will open a file browser window that will allow you to browse for an image. [5] X Research source Depending on your version of Photoshop, you may see Place Embedded and Place Linked . For this method, click Place Embedded if you see it.

steps.title: Navigate to select an image.
steps.content: Navigate to select an image. Use the file browser window to browse files on your computer. Click on an image to select it. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Click Place.
steps.content: Click Place . This will place the image in the Photoshop file or image as a new layer. [7] X Research source Before you can continue editing your image, you must click the checkmark at the top of the screen to confirm the placement of your image.

steps.title: Open Photoshop and open an image or Photoshop file.
steps.content: Open Photoshop and open an image or Photoshop file. You can either open an existing Photoshop file or image, or create a new Photoshop file.

steps.title: Click File.
steps.content: Click File . It's in the menu bar at the top of the screen. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Click Place.
steps.content: Click Place . This will open a file browser window that will allow you to browse for an image. [9] X Research source Depending on your version of Photoshop, you may see Place Embedded and Place Linked . For this method, click Place Linked if you see it.

steps.title: Paste the URL to an image in the "File name" box.
steps.content: Paste the URL to an image in the "File name" box. If you don't have the URL copied, go back to the image in your web browser and right-click it (or Ctrl -click, if you’re on a Mac with no right mouse button), then choose Copy image address . The image must end in a valid file format (for example, .jpg, .png, .bmp) for Photoshop to open it. Older versions of Photoshop can't open .webp files.

steps.title: Click Place.
steps.content: Click Place . This will place the image in the Photoshop file or image as a new layer. [10] X Research source Before you can continue editing your image, you must click the checkmark at the top of the screen to confirm the placement of your image.

steps.title: Open an image you want to insert into Photoshop.
steps.content: Open an image you want to insert into Photoshop. This could be an image on your computer already, or one from the internet.

steps.title: Open Photoshop, if it's not already open.
steps.content: Open Photoshop, if it's not already open. If you want to add the image as a new layer, make sure the image you want to add the layer to is open in Photoshop, as well.

steps.title: Drag and drop the image into Photoshop.
steps.content: Drag and drop the image into Photoshop. Photoshop will create a new layer for the image automatically.
